Jerry Green - The Hardest Working Man in Show Business

Louisville entertainer Jerry Green combs his hair in the bathroom of his home south of Louisville. The preparation of his appearance on show nights is something he decided to make a signature with early on in his career. "I like to be clean cut. That's what I want to portray. Someone that is classy and dressy," Green said. Dec. 5, 2014

Jerry Green - The Hardest Working Man in Show Business

Buy Photo
Louisville entertainer Jerry Green combs his hair in the bathroom of his home south of Louisville. The preparation of his appearance on show nights is something he decided to make a signature with early on in his career. "I like to be clean cut. That's what I want to portray. Someone that is classy and dressy," Green said. Dec. 5, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
Buy Photo
Fullscreen
Buy Photo
Green brings a few changes of outfits with him each night to his shows. Each is ironed and placed in to a garment bag with not a detail missed. From the cuff links to the rings on his fingers, it's clear each piece was given careful consideration. Dec. 5, 2014   , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Buy Photo
Green pulls on the first jacket he will be wearing during his show Friday evening at his night club Jerry Green and Friends. " I always loved to play dress up," Green said with a laugh. "I have a purple jacket that I wear each night when I perform Prince's "Purple Rain."" Dec. 5, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Patrons and members of the Jerry Green and Friends band prepare to exit the lounge at a rainy three a.m. following their Friday night show. Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

A view of the flourescent Jerry Green and Friends sign sits behind the performer's microphone on an empty stage early Friday evening. Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
Buy Photo
Fullscreen
Buy Photo
Bill May, 66, has been coming to see Jerry Green play for over a decade, coming at least three to four nights-a-week. "I first met Jerry back at the Best Western when the club was off of Brownsboro Road," May said. "I've been coming ever since." Like many of the loyal patrons, it's the quality of the music that has always kept May coming back. "Jerry's one of he best performers here in Louisville," May said. "Once you've been here, you pass it a long to a friend. You have to go to Jerry's club for a good time." Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
Buy Photo
Fullscreen
Buy Photo
When musician and music fan Mike Bell moved to Louisville from Washington, D.C. he set out to find a good place in town for his time off. After some asking around, he found himself inside Jerry Green's night club. "Jerry Green is one of the best musicians I've ever met," Bell said. "It was classy." The diversity of the people in the night club stood out to Bell and Green's meticulous approach to the music. "He reminds me of James Brown. If the band made a mistake, you'll see him turn around." After all of the years coming to the club, Bell is one of the regulars that call Jerry a friend. "He's a genuine person. A man of integrity," Bell said. "If he says he's going to do something, he's going to do it 100 percent." Dec. 6, 2014   , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
Buy Photo
Fullscreen
Buy Photo
"I proposed to her right here at Jerry Green's," Dominick Barksdale, left, said in regard to his wife Tiffany Barksdale. Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
Buy Photo
Fullscreen
Buy Photo
Louisville entertainer Jerry Green is announced each week at his club beneath the Breckinridge Hotel as the "Hardest working man in show business." Any one that has seen him perform live may find that claim hard to debate. At 62, Green still leaves the stage each night Friday and Saturday night completely drenched in sweat. With a music career that began in his teenage years, Green still treats it's show like it could be his last. "I try to do every song like it's the first song," Green said. "I want my best to shine at all times." Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
Buy Photo
Fullscreen
Buy Photo
Freddy George plays the piano early Friday evening in Jerry Green and Friends nightclub. Dec. 5, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
Buy Photo
Fullscreen
Buy Photo
A portrait of Robert Davis hangs in loving memory on the wall above the table that was his nightly spot inside Jerry Green and Friends night club. Davis was a regular from the beginning and as a result had his very one table permanently reserved. "We always called him 'our Bob'," Green said with a laugh. "He will be missed," Green wrote in his book "A View from the Stage." Dec. 5, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Jerry Green and Friends saxophone player Upshaw Briggs on Friday evening in the nightclub. Dec. 5, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Jerry Green and Friends band members Shawn Pitts, left, and keyboard Billy Ross. Dec. 5, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Jerry Green begins his Friday night set at his club underneath the Breckinridge Hotel opening with "?????". "When I first hit the stage I may know the first song, but I won't know the rest until I look at the crowd," Green said. Dec. 5, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Buy Photo
Green wipes sweat from his brow as the night begins to pick up speed with Tina Metzler, from left, Pam Lambert, and Cindy Vaughn taking to the floor on a relatively slow Friday night. "It doesn't matter matter if you're black, white, pink, orange or what," Green said. "You come through those doors, you can check your color at the door, because we're going to have a good time." Dec. 5, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Crooning out a ballad, Jerry Green clutches his microphone inside his hankerchief, during a Friday night show. "The crowds they just feel you with energy," Green said. "You just want to put out your very best and hope it comes back to you and most of the time, it does." Dec. 5, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Norma moves to a slow song Friday evening inside Jerry Green and Friend's nightclub. Dec. 5, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Buy Photo
The floor starts to fill up on a Friday night at Jerry Green and Friends. Saturday nights are typically the busiest nights of the week. "I read the crowd all of the time," Green said. "That's the longevity to me. Being able to see what's in this room and play to it." Green and his band will perform songs ranging from R&B to country. Louie Armstrong to Phantom of the Opera. Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Earlene Green Thompson, left, Jerry Green's sister, takes money from Kaba Kolata during the performance of "Last Two Dollars" inside Jerry Green's nightclub Friday. Earlene and Jerry perform the song together every Friday and Saturday night. Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Jerry Green spreads his arms showing off his purple jacket that he wears each night while performing Prince's "Purple Rain." At 62, Green still comes at the stage with the energy of a man in his 20s. "I'm going to sing until I can't sing anymore," Green said. "When the time comes, the time comes." Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal

Fullscreen
Buy Photo
The red stage lights shine down on Jerry Green during his Friday night performance at the Jerry Green and Friends night club. The local legend began strumming on a broom when he was six years old growing up in the Newburg neighborhood in Louisville, Ky. One of ten siblings, it was decided early on that Jerry was the best singer of the lot. He would go on to be in bands with acts that took him on tours around the USA and the world. "At a young age I just loved music," Green said. "I'd listen to my father play and I just wanted to play that guitar." Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
Buy Photo
Fullscreen
Buy Photo
Donna Toogood is spun by her dance partner Friday evening at Jerry Green and Friends nightclub. Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
Buy Photo
Fullscreen
Buy Photo
Jerry Green hits a high chord as he belts in to his microphone during a Friday night performance at the Jerry Green and Friends night club under the Breckinridge Hotel. "I want my legacy to be known as a place that you could just come and have a good time," Green said. Green, 62, has had a music career that spans over nearly five decades and in 2014 he celebrated 20 years running his signature night club. "It's woven in to the fabric of my soul," Green said. Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
Buy Photo
Fullscreen
Buy Photo
Green holds his microphone in to the air after performing Prince's "Purple Rain" during a Friday night show. While his performance touches on a variety of singers, Green's range is impressive. "I want it to be as perfect as I can get it," Green said. "Sometimes I just look out at the audience and smile. All of these people come together and enjoy themselves." Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
Buy Photo
Fullscreen
Buy Photo
Jerry Green wipes the sweat from his forehead in the back hallway, just off of the stage, following the night a Friday night performance. The full-set lasted nearly three hours and included multiple outfit changes. "You are only as good as your last show," Green said. "You can do a thousand good shows, bt you do one bad one... that's the one people will judge you on." Dec. 6, 2014  , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal
